depth_explanation.initialising: Engine is initialising or waiting for a move.
depth_explanation.surface: At depth {depth} ({fullMoves} full move{s} ahead) the engine catches only the most obvious immediate tactics. Useful for quick blunder checks.
depth_explanation.shallow: Depth {depth} means Stockfish is looking {halfMoves} half-moves (≈{fullMoves} full moves) ahead. Short tactical combinations — forks, pins, and simple exchanges — are reliably found here.
depth_explanation.standard: Depth {depth} ({halfMoves} half-moves ahead) is where solid tactical analysis begins. Most one-move threats and two-move combinations are clearly visible to the engine.
depth_explanation.deep: At depth {depth} Stockfish searches {halfMoves} half-moves ahead. It is now evaluating multi-piece combinations, sacrifices, and medium-horizon strategic plans with high confidence.
depth_explanation.very_deep: Depth {depth} — {halfMoves} half-moves of full tree search. Analysis at this level uncovers deep combinations that humans rarely see over the board. Evaluations are highly reliable.
depth_explanation.extreme: Depth {depth} is extreme. Stockfish is exploring {halfMoves} half-moves ahead, far beyond human calculation. At this depth the principal variation reflects near-optimal play for both sides.

score_explanation.equal: The position is equal — neither side has a meaningful advantage.
score_explanation.slight_edge: {side} has a very slight edge (+{abs} pawns). Both sides have good practical chances.
score_explanation.small_advantage: {side} holds a small advantage (+{abs} pawns). Precise play is needed to convert.
score_explanation.clearly_better: {side} is clearly better (+{abs} pawns). This advantage is equivalent to roughly one minor piece.
score_explanation.winning: {side} is winning (+{abs} pawns). A decisive material or positional edge exists.
score_explanation.dominant: {side} has a dominant advantage (+{abs} pawns). The game is effectively decided with best play.
score_explanation.mate_white: White has a forced checkmate in {n} move{s}.
score_explanation.mate_black: Black has a forced checkmate in {n} move{s}.

why_depth_panel.explanation: Chess has roughly 35 legal moves per position. Every extra ply (half-move) multiplies the search tree by ~35×. Shallow searches miss deep combinations; deeper searches find lines that no human could calculate at the board. Stockfish uses alpha-beta pruning and NNUE (neural-network) evaluation to cut irrelevant branches and reach high depths efficiently.
